questions.text: Which of the following muscles is not involved in the overhead abduction of the arm?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Pectoralis major

Explanation:

  • Pectoralis major: The pectoralis major muscle is not directly involved in the overhead abduction of the arm. Its primary action is to adduct and internally rotate the arm, as in movements such as hugging or pressing the arms against the body. It does not play a significant role in raising the arm in an overhead position.

 

Movement of the shoulder joint

Muscle(s) Involved

Other movements

Adduction
  • Pectoralis major
  • Teres major
  • Latissimus dorsi
  • Coracobrachialis
  • Short head of biceps brachii
  • Long head of triceps brachii
  • Medial rotation of scapula

Abduction
  • Supraspinatus (0-15) and deltoid (15-90)
  • Serratus anterior (90°–180°)
  • Upper and lower fibers of trapezius (90°–180°)
  • Humerus elevation
  • Clavicle axial rotation
  • AC joint movement
  • Lateral rotation of scapula

Serratus anterior (Option A): The serratus anterior muscle plays an important role in stabilizing and upwardly rotating the scapula during arm abduction.

Deltoid (Option B): The deltoid muscle, which is located on the shoulder, is a key muscle involved in the abduction of the arm.

Trapezius (Option C): The trapezius muscle, a large muscle in the upper back and neck region, also contributes to the overhead abduction of the arm.

questions.text: Identify the part of the respiratory tract based on the image given below.
questions.solution:
Correct answer Option A) Respiratory bronchiole

Airway Region

Epithelium

Wall Components

Functions

Bronchi

Respiratory Epithelium

Hyaline cartilage plates, smooth muscle

Conduct air

Bronchioles

Simple cuboidal to columnar (cilia, club)

No cartilage, smooth muscle (first region without)

Conduct air; constrict/dilate

Terminal Bronchioles

Simple cuboidal (cilia, club)

Thinner smooth muscle

Conduct air; produce protective/surfactant-like secretions

Respiratory Bronchioles

Simple cuboidal (cilia, club), alveolar regions

(Option A)

Small smooth muscle bundles

Conduct air; secrete; some gas exchange

Alveolar Ducts

Simple cuboidal interspersed with alveolar

Small, thin smooth muscle bundles

Conduct air; participate in gas exchange

Alveoli

Type I & II pneumocytes

Reticular & elastic fibers

Main site for gas exchange, surfactant production

questions.text: The structure marked in the image drains into:

choices.text: Junction of superior vena cava and left brachiocephalic veins

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Thoracic Duct

Explanation:

  • The marked structure is the thoracic duct.
  • The thoracic duct runs in the thorax and is the continuation of the cisterna chyli. It drains all body parts except the right half above the diaphragm.
  • Left-sided trunks empty into it, and it ultimately drains into the left venous angle.

Thoracic Duct:

  • Function: Main lymphatic trunk, draining chyle and most lymph into the bloodstream.
  • Drainage Area: Entire body except the right side of the head, neck, upper limb, lung, thoracic wall, right heart, and convex liver surface.
  • Origin: Upper end of cisterna chyli (T12).
  • Course:
    • Enters thorax via aortic opening of the diaphragm.
    • Ascends in posterior mediastinum behind the esophagus.
    • At T5, inclines left and moves into the superior mediastinum.
  • Termination: Ends at C7, draining into the left venous angle (junction of left internal jugular and subclavian veins).

 

(Options A, C, and D ruled out)

questions.text: A patient developed the following deformity, after overhead (weight-lifting) exercises. Which of the following muscles is involved?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Serratus anterior

Explanation:

  • The Serratus Anterior muscle is located on the lateral aspect of the thorax and attaches to the medial border of the scapula.
  • It is primarily responsible for protracting and stabilizing the scapula against the thoracic wall.
  • Weakness or dysfunction of the Serratus Anterior can result in winged scapula, where the medial border of the scapula protrudes away from the thoracic wall.

Serratus Anterior:

  • Origin: Upper 8 ribs (anterolaterally)
  • Insertion: Costal surface of the scapula
  • Nerve Supply: Long thoracic nerve (C5, C6, C7 – "Wings to Heaven")
  • Function:
    • Protracts the scapula (pulls it forward)
    • Holds scapula against the thoracic wall (prevents winging)
    • Rotates the scapula laterally (turning the glenoid cavity upwards for full overhead abduction)

Injury to Long Thoracic Nerve:

  • Causes Winging of Scapula
  • Seen in post-mastectomy cases, trauma, weightlifting injuries
  • Patient has difficulty in overhead abduction (arm cannot be fully raised)

 

Trapezius (Option A): Dysfunction of the trapezius (innervated by the spinal accessory nerve, CN XI) causes drooping of the shoulder, but not classic scapular winging.

Latissimus dorsi (Option C): This muscle helps in adduction, extension, and medial rotation of the humerus. It is innervated by the thoracodorsal nerve and does not cause scapular winging.

Supraspinatus (Option D): This muscle initiates arm abduction (first 15°) and is innervated by the suprascapular nerve. It is not responsible for scapular stability. Incorrect.

questions.text: The type of joint marked in the image below is:
questions.solution:
Answer: D) Synovial

Explanation:

The costotransverse joint is a synovial joint that forms between:

  • The tubercle of the rib
  • The transverse process of the corresponding thoracic vertebra

It is a plane-type synovial joint, allowing slight gliding movements during respiration.

Type of joint

Examples

Hinge Joint

Elbow joint, Knee joint, Temporomandibular joint.

Pivot Joint

Superior radioulnar joint, C1 and C2 joint

Ball-and-Socket Joint

Shoulder (glenohumeral) joint, Hip joint

Saddle Joint

Sternoclavicular joint, Carpometacarpal joint of the thumb

Ellipsoid (Condyloid) Joint

Radiocarpal (wrist) joint, atlantooccipital joint, Metacarpophalangeal joints

 

Aspect

Hinge Joints (Bicondylar Joints)

Pivot Joints (Trochoid Joints)

Movement

Predominantly uniaxial with limited rotation around a second orthogonal axis.

Uniaxial rotation around an axis.

Structure

Formed by two convex condyles that articulate with concave or flat surfaces.

Involves an osseous pivot rotating within an osteoligamentous ring, or vice versa.

Examples
  • Knee Joint- Condyles may be within a single fibrous capsule.
  • Temporomandibular joint- In separate capsules that work together.]
  • Humeroulnar joint in the elbow.
  • Superior radioulnar joint- The head of the radius rotates within the annular ligament and ulnar radial notch.
  • Dens of the axis (C2 vertebra) project into altas.
  • C1 and C2 joint that allows the head to move back and forth.

Images

Incorrect Options:

Syndesmosis (option A): A fibrous joint with bones connected by ligaments or interosseous membranes (e.g., distal tibiofibular joint).

Synarthrosis (option B): A non-movable joint, typically seen in skull sutures. Costotransverse joints allow movement, making this option incorrect.

Synchondrosis (option C): A cartilaginous joint where bones are joined by hyaline cartilage (e.g., first costochondral joint). Costotransverse joints are not primarily cartilaginous.

questions.text: Identify the level of the cross-section shown in the image below:-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) T3-T4

Explanation:

  • The image shows the arch of the aorta, brachiocephalic trunk, left common carotid artery, and left subclavian artery, we can make an inference about the level of the cross-section.
  • The cross-section shown in the image corresponds to the level between the T3 and T4 vertebrae.

At this level, the aortic arch is usually seen, and the trachea begins to bifurcate into the right and left main bronchi.

  • Level of the Thoracic Inlet: This is at the top of the thoracic cavity, where the trachea and esophagus enter.
  • Level of the Aortic Arch: Located around the T4-T5 vertebral level, where the aorta arches over the left main bronchus.
  • Level of the Carina: At the T5-T6 level, this is where the trachea bifurcates into the right and left main bronchi.
  • Level of the Heart: The heart is typically seen from T6 to T9. You can identify the chambers (right atrium, left atrium, ventricles) and major vessels (aorta, pulmonary arteries).
  • Level of the Diaphragm: The diaphragm typically corresponds to the T10 vertebral level, which can help in distinguishing between thoracic and abdominal structures.
  • Level of the Esophagus: The esophagus runs along the midline and can be seen at various levels, usually starting from the cervical region down to T10.
  • Level of the Thoracic Spine: The thoracic vertebrae can be used as references; typically, there are 12 thoracic vertebrae.

 

Fig: Showing CT view of axial section of the thorax

 

T1-T2 (Option A): This option indicates a cross-section at the level between the T1 and T2 vertebrae, which is different from the structures mentioned in the image description.

T2-T3 (Option B): This option indicates a cross-section at the level between the T2 and T3 vertebrae, which is also different from the structures mentioned in the image description.

T4-T5 (Option D): This option indicates a cross-section at the level between the T4 and T5 vertebrae, which is not consistent with the structures seen in the image.

questions.text: Identify the labeling correctly:

choices.text: A- Superior vena cava, B- Ascending aorta, C- Pulmonary trunk, D- Descending aorta
A- Ascending aorta, B- Descending aorta, C- Pulmonary trunk, D- Superior vena cava
A- Ascending aorta, B- Superior vena cava, C- Descending aorta, D- Pulmonary trunk,
A- Ascending aorta, B- Superior Vena Cava, C- Pulmonary trunk, D- Descending aorta

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - A- , B-Ascending aorta , C- Pulmonary trunk, D- Descending aorta:

  • A. Superior vena cava: The superior vena cava is a large vein that carries deoxygenated blood from the upper half of the body to the right atrium of the heart. It is located anterior and slightly to the right of the ascending aorta.

  • B. Ascending aorta:  The ascending aorta arises from the left ventricle of the heart and is the initial portion of the aorta that moves upward before arching.

  • C. Pulmonary Trunk: The pulmonary trunk is the vessel that arises from the right ventricle and bifurcates into the left and right pulmonary arteries, which carry deoxygenated blood to the lungs. It is positioned anterior to the ascending aorta and the superior vena cava.

  • D. Descending Aorta: The descending aorta continues from the aortic arch and runs downwards behind the heart, supplying blood to the lower parts of the body. It is located posterior to the heart and more to the left in the thoracic cavity.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B , C, D incorrectly labels the structures

questions.text: A patient presented with paradoxical respiration. Which of the following nerves is most likely to be affected?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Phrenic Nerve

Explanation:

  • Phrenic Nerve: The phrenic nerve is indeed the most likely nerve to be affected in a patient with paradoxical respiration. The phrenic nerve plays a critical role in controlling the contraction of the diaphragm, the primary muscle involved in breathing. Damage or dysfunction of the phrenic nerve can result in weakened or paralyzed diaphragm movement, leading to paradoxical respiration where the chest moves inward during inhalation and outward during exhalation.

 

Feature

Right Phrenic Nerve

Left Phrenic Nerve

Length and Course

Shorter and more vertical

Longer and less vertical

Relation to Subclavian Artery

Separated from second part by scalenus anterior

Passes anterior to first part

Relation to Major Vessels

Passes lateral to superior vena cava

Passes anterior to aortic arch

Relation to Heart

Passes lateral to right atrium

Passes over left atrium and ventricle

Diaphragm Entry

Through central tendon (caval foramen or just lateral)

Through muscular part, anterior to central tendon

Associated Ganglion

Right phrenic ganglion, sometimes with accessory ganglion

Left phrenic ganglion (less common)

 

Right Vagus Nerve (Option A):

  • While right vagus nerve injury can lead to respiratory issues, it doesn't directly control the diaphragm, reducing its likelihood as a cause of paradoxical respiration.

 

Left Vagus Nerve (Option B):

  • While the left vagus nerve regulates thoracic and abdominal functions, it's not the primary nerve for diaphragmatic control.

 

Recurrent Laryngeal Nerve (Option C):

  • While damage to the recurrent laryngeal nerve can result in vocal cord paralysis or weakness, it is not directly related to the innervation of the diaphragm.

questions.text: Reticular fibers are not present in which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Thymus

Explanation:

  • Reticular fibers are a type of connective tissue fibers composed of collagen type III.
  • They form a delicate network of fibers that provide structural support to various organs and tissues.
  • Reticular fibers are particularly abundant in lymphoid organs, where they form the framework for immune cell localization and function.
  • Unlike other lymphoid organs, the thymus does not contain reticular fibers.
  • Instead, it has a unique structural framework composed of epithelial cells called thymic epithelial cells.

Reticular fibers: are fine, branching fibers composed of collagen, providing structural support to organs with a rich lymphoreticular or hepatocyte system. These fibers are found in:

  • Lymph nodes
  • Liver
  • Spleen

However, reticular fibers are absent in the thymus, despite it being part of the lymphatic system.

 

Lymph node, Bone marrow, Spleen (Options B, C, and D): Reticular fibers are seen

questions.text: What is the most common complication of the central line insertion below the marked bone?
questions.solution:
The most common complication of central line insertion below the clavicle (subclavian vein approach) is arterial puncture. This occurs when the subclavian artery is inadvertently punctured during the procedure. The subclavian vein lies posterior and inferior to the clavicle, making it prone to accidental arterial injury.

Complications of Central Line Insertion (Subclavian Approach):

Complication

Description

Arterial puncture

The most common complication; can cause hematoma or hemorrhage.

Pneumothorax

Risk due to proximity to the lung apex.

Thrombophlebitis

Less common, but can occur due to catheter irritation.

Chylothorax

Rare, occurs if the thoracic duct (left side) is injured.

Infection (Empyema, Sepsis)

Can occur if strict aseptic precautions are not maintained.

Thrombophlebitis (Option B): Incorrect, because it is less common compared to arterial puncture.

Empyema (Option C): Incorrect, as infection-related complications occur later, not acutely.

Chylothorax (Option D): Incorrect, as it is rare and occurs only on the left side due to thoracic duct injury.

questions.text: Identify the arrow-marked chamber.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Left Atrium

Explanation:

The left atrium is located posteriorly in the heart and receives oxygenated blood from the pulmonary veins. In cross-sectional imaging, it is centrally positioned and posterior to the right atrium and ventricles. The given image corresponds to a transverse section of the heart, showing the left atrium in its expected anatomical location.

Anatomy of the Chambers of the Heart

Feature

Right Atrium

Right Ventricle

Left Atrium

Left Ventricle

Location

Right, anterior

Right, inferior

Left, posterior

Left, inferior

Function

Receives deoxygenated blood from vena cava

Pumps deoxygenated blood to the lungs via pulmonary artery

Receives oxygenated blood from pulmonary veins

Pumps oxygenated blood to the body via aorta

Wall Thickness

Thin

Thin

Thin

Thickest

Valves Associated

Tricuspid Valve

Pulmonary Valve

Mitral Valve

Aortic Valve

Key Structures

Crista terminalis, fossa ovalis

Trabeculae carneae, moderator band

Pulmonary veins opening, interatrial septum

Papillary muscles, chordae tendineae

The left atrium lies posteriorly and superiorly, making it distinct in cross-sectional anatomy. It is crucial in pulmonary circulation, ensuring efficient oxygenated blood flow into the left ventricle.

Right Atrium (Option A): Incorrect because the right atrium is anterior and positioned to the right, unlike the marked posterior chamber.

Right Ventricle (Option C): Incorrect because the right ventricle is more anterior and lies inferior to the right atrium.

Left Ventricle (Option D): Incorrect because the left ventricle is thicker-walled and positioned inferiorly compared to the left atrium.

questions.text: Which of the following is wrongly labeled here?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Subscapular artery

Explanation:

  • The subscapular artery is the largest branch of the axillary artery and arises from its third part.
  • It soon divides into the circumflex scapular artery and thoracodorsal artery.
  • In the given image, the structure labeled as the subscapular artery appears to be incorrectly marked, likely representing another artery.

Branches of the Axillary Artery

Part of Axillary Artery

Branches

First Part (proximal to pectoralis minor)

Superior thoracic artery

Second Part (behind pectoralis minor)

Thoracoacromial artery, Lateral thoracic artery

Third Part (distal to pectoralis minor)

Subscapular artery, Anterior circumflex humeral artery, Posterior circumflex humeral artery

 

Superior thoracic artery (Option A): Correctly labeled.

Thoracoacromial artery (Option B): Correctly labeled.

Posterior circumflex artery (Option D): Correctly labeled

questions.text: Match the auscultatory areas of the heart from the image given below.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 1-Aortic, 2-Pulmonary, 3-Tricuspid, 4-Mitral

Explanation:

The auscultatory areas of the heart correspond to the locations where the heart valves' sounds are best heard:

  1. Aortic area- Right 2nd intercostal space (near the sternum).
  2. Pulmonary area- Left 2nd intercostal space (near the sternum).
  3. Tricuspid area- Left lower sternal border (around 4th intercostal space).
  4. Mitral area (Apex beat)- 5th intercostal space at the midclavicular line.

Auscultation of Heart Sounds

Valve

Auscultation Site

Location

Aortic valve

Right 2nd ICS, parasternal

Best for aortic stenosis murmur

Pulmonary valve

Left 2nd ICS, parasternal

Best for pulmonary stenosis murmur

Tricuspid valve

Left 4th ICS, parasternal

Best for tricuspid regurgitation murmur

Mitral valve

Left 5th ICS, midclavicular line (apex beat)

Best for mitral regurgitation/stenosis murmur

questions.text: Identify the arrow-marked chamber?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Right ventricle

Explanation:

  • The structure marked in the above scan is the right ventricle.
  • Level of the Thoracic Inlet: This is at the top of the thoracic cavity, where the trachea and esophagus enter.
  • Level of the Aortic Arch: Located around the T4-T5 vertebral level, where the aorta arches over the left main bronchus.
  • Level of the Carina: At the T5-T6 level, this is where the trachea bifurcates into the right and left main bronchi.
  • Level of the Heart: The heart is typically seen from T6 to T9. You can identify the chambers (right atrium, left atrium, ventricles) and major vessels (aorta, pulmonary arteries).
  • Level of the Diaphragm: The diaphragm typically corresponds to the T10 vertebral level, which can help in distinguishing between thoracic and abdominal structures.
  • Level of the Esophagus: The esophagus runs along the midline and can be seen at various levels, usually starting from the cervical region down to T10.
  • Level of the Thoracic Spine: The thoracic vertebrae can be used as references; typically, there are 12 thoracic vertebrae.

questions.text: At which vertebral level is the anatomical cross-section shown in the image provided?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - T10:

  • Visible Structures:

    • Both right and left lungs.

    • Liver

    • Esophagus

    • Spleen

  • Explanation: At the T10 level, both lungs are visible, indicating the presence of thoracic structures. The liver, esophagus, and spleen are also visible, which is consistent with this level. At T11 and T12, the lungs start to taper off and may not be fully visible. The absence of the colon is also noted at this level, confirming T10 as the correct answer.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - T12:

  • Visible Structures:

    • Lungs are not visible.

    • Liver

    • Esophagus

    • Spleen

  • Explanation: At T12, the lungs are typically not visible, as they taper off around the lower thoracic levels. The presence of the liver, esophagus, and spleen can be noted, but the key distinguishing feature is the absence of lung visibility, which rules out T12 for the given image.

Option C - T11:

  • Visible Structures:

    • Lungs start to taper off and may not be fully visible.

    • Liver

    • Esophagus

    • Spleen

  • Explanation: Similar to T12, at T11 the lungs are less visible as they begin to taper off. This is inconsistent with the observation that both lungs are visible in the given cross-section, thus ruling out T11.

Option D - T9:

  • Visible Structures:

    • Both right and left lungs.

    • Liver (partially).

    • Esophagus.

    • Spleen is not typically visible.

  • Explanation: At T9, both lungs are visible, and the superior aspect of the liver starts to appear. However, the spleen is usually not visible at this level, which contradicts the given cross-section details.

questions.text: Identify the artery that supplies the anatomical region of the heart shown in the provided image.
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Anterior Interventricular Artery (Left Anterior Descending Artery):

  • The anterior interventricular artery, also known as the left anterior descending (LAD) artery, is responsible for supplying the anterior part of the interventricular septum and the anterior walls of both ventricles.

  • Associated Regions:

    • Anterior wall of the left ventricle.

    • Part of the right ventricle.

    • Anterior two-thirds of the interventricular septum.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Left Circumflex Artery

  • Supplies the lateral and posterior walls of the left ventricle and part of the left atrium.

  • Associated Regions:

    • Lateral wall of the left ventricle.

    • Posterior wall of the left ventricle.

    • Part of the left atrium.

Option C - Left Marginal Artery:

  • Function: Supplies the left margin (or border) of the heart.

  • Details: It is a branch of the left circumflex artery and runs along the margin of the left ventricle.

  • Associated Regions:

    • Lateral wall of the left ventricle, especially along the margin.

Option D - Right Coronary Artery (RCA):

  • Supplies the right atrium, right ventricle, and part of the left ventricle, as well as the sinoatrial (SA) and atrioventricular (AV) nodes.

  • Associated Regions:

    • Right atrium.

    • Right ventricle.

    • Inferior wall of the left ventricle.

    • SA and AV nodes.

questions.text: Identify the marked structure?
questions.solution:
Option A - Anterior end of Rib:

  • The image shown is a chest X-ray in PA view, as indicated by the rib reaching the midline (vertebrae). Posterior ribs appear more horizontal, while anterior ribs are more oblique. The anterior end of the rib cannot be seen attached to the vertebrae because costal cartilages are not visible in an X-ray. The arrow is pointing to the anterior rib, making Option A the correct answer

Incorrect Options:

  • Option B, C and D: Refer to explanation of Option A

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the anatomy of the breast?

choices.text: The superior medial quadrant has more tissue
The axillary tail of Spence crosses the anterior axillary fold
The nipple is located at the level of the fourth intercostal space in most women

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - The axillary tail of Spence crosses the anterior axillary fold:

  • The axillary tail of Spence is an extension of the breast tissue that extends into the axilla, and it does cross the anterior axillary fold.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - The superior medial quadrant has more tissue:

  • The superior lateral quadrant actually contains the most glandular tissue and is a common site for breast cancer.

Option B - There are 10 lobules present:

  • The human breast typically has 15-20 lobules, not just 10.

Option D - The nipple is located at the level of the fourth intercostal space in most women:

  • While the nipple is commonly said to be at the level of the fourth intercostal space, this can vary greatly among individuals and is not a definitive anatomical landmark for all women.

questions.text: Identify the vascular structure marked in the given radiology image?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Aberrant right subclavian artery:

  • This is a common vascular anomaly where the right subclavian artery arises abnormally from the aortic arch and travels behind the esophagus to the right arm.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Aberrant left subclavian artery:

  • An aberrant left subclavian artery is a rare anomaly compared to the right.

  • It would arise from the right side and travel to the left, but this is not the typical presentation of aberrant subclavian arteries.

Option C - Ascending aorta:

  • The ascending aorta is the initial section of the aorta arising from the heart and extending upwards.

  • It would not have the characteristic path seen in an aberrant subclavian artery.

Option D - Main pulmonary artery:

  • The main pulmonary artery carries deoxygenated blood from the right ventricle to the lungs.

  • Its course and branching are distinct and do not resemble the path of an aberrant subclavian artery.

questions.text: Which structure is located approximately 25 cm from the central incisor?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Arch of Aorta

Explanation:

The arch of the aorta is positioned around the level of the T4 vertebra, which is roughly 23 cm from the central incisor.

questions.text: During the surgical procedure for Patent Ductus Arteriosus, the structure that is in close relation to it can be damaged. Which of the following can be the structure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Left recurrent laryngeal nerve

Explanation:

  • The left recurrent laryngeal nerve (a branch of the vagus nerve) loops around the arch of the aorta, near the ductus arteriosus (ligamentum arteriosum in adults).
  • Due to this close relationship, it is vulnerable to damage during PDA surgery.

Feature

Right Recurrent Laryngeal Nerve (Option B)

Left Recurrent Laryngeal Nerve

Pathway

Loops around the right subclavian artery

Loops around the arch of the aorta

Relation to Inferior Thyroid Artery

Lies between the branches of the inferior thyroid artery (can be anterior or posterior)

Lies posterior to the inferior thyroid artery

Course

Shorter course in the neck

Longer course in the neck

Prone to Injury In

Thyroid surgeries (more prone to injury than left side)

Mediastinal pathologies (due to its longer course)

Affected by Mediastinal Pathologies

No, as it loops around the subclavian artery (outside the mediastinum)

Yes, as it loops around the aortic arch (within the mediastinum)

Clinical Condition

Less affected by cardiac pathologies

Ortner’s Syndrome (Mitral stenosis → Left atrial enlargement → Compression of left recurrent laryngeal nerve → Hoarseness of voice)

Thoracic duct (Option C): Located on the left side of the thorax, but it is not closely related to the PDA.

Hemiazygos vein (Option D): Lies posteriorly in the thorax and is not in direct contact with the PDA.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked in the given image
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Pulmonary trunk

Explanation:

  • The marked structure in the given image is the pulmonary trunk.
  • The pulmonary trunk starts from the upper part of the right ventricle, near the left 3rd costal cartilage, and runs backward and leftward.
  • It ends beneath the aortic arch, in front of the left principal bronchus, dividing into the right and left pulmonary arteries.

(Options A, B, and C ruled out)

Main pulmonary trunk:

  • Pulmonary trunk - Carries blood to the pulmonary circulation.
  • The pulmonary trunk, originating from the upper right ventricle, is approximately 5 cm long.
  • It curves back and to the left through the middle mediastinum before dividing into the right and left pulmonary arteries below the aortic arch and in front of the left bronchus.
  • Divides into left and right at the T4-T5 level.

questions.text: A defect in which of the following pharyngeal arch artery causes the defect shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Left 6th arch artery

Explanation:

  • The condition shown in the image is Patent Ductus Arteriosus (PDA), a congenital heart defect where the ductus arteriosus (a fetal blood vessel connecting the pulmonary artery to the aorta) fails to close after birth.
  • The ductus arteriosus is derived from the left 6th pharyngeal arch artery.

Pharyngeal Arch

Artery of Arch

First

Maxillary artery

Second

Hyoid artery, Stapedial artery

Third

Common carotid artery, Internal carotid artery

Fourth

Arch of aorta (left side), Subclavian artery (right side)

Sixth

Ductus arteriosus (left side), Pulmonary artery (right side)

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the right coronary artery?

choices.text: It’s diameter is less than left coronary artery
It arises from the right aortic sinus
It gives rise to circumflex coronary branch
Right conal artery is it’s first branch

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - It gives rise to the circumflex coronary branch.

This statement is false. The right coronary artery does not typically give rise to the circumflex coronary branch. The circumflex branch is a branch of the left coronary artery. It wraps around the left side of the heart and supplies blood to the left atrium and portions of the left ventricle.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Its diameter is less than the left coronary artery.

This statement is generally true.Left coronary artery (LCA) typically has a slightly larger diameter than the the right coronary artery (RCA)

Option B - It arises from the anterior aortic sinus.

This statement is true. The right coronary artery originates from the right aortic sinus, which is one of the three aortic sinuses located at the base of the aorta.

Option D - Right conal artery is its first branch.

This statement is true. The right conal artery is indeed the first branch of the right coronary artery.

questions.text: Which of the following veins drain directly into the brachiocephalic vein?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Left superior intercostal vein

  • The left superior intercostal vein collects blood from the 2nd and 3rd posterior intercostal veins on the left side of the body and typically directs this blood flow into the left brachiocephalic vein.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Hemiazygous vein: Instead of directly connecting to the brachiocephalic vein, it usually joins with the azygous vein, which then empties into the superior vena cava.

Option B: Superior thyroid veins: The superior and middle thyroid veins drain the thyroid gland, flowing into the internal jugular vein rather than directly into the brachiocephalic vein.

Option C: Right superior intercostal vein: The right superior intercostal vein drains upper right intercostal spaces, usually joining the azygous vein before reaching the superior vena cava, rather than directly connecting to the brachiocephalic vein.

questions.text: What is the most prominent indication of breast cancer among the options provided?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Peau d’orange

  • Peau d'orange refers to the appearance of the breast skin that resembles the texture of an orange peel. It is caused by the infiltration and thickening of the breast skin due to underlying breast cancer. This condition is characterized by dimpling, puckering, or indentation of the skin, giving it a pebbled or orange peel-like appearance. It occurs due to the obstruction or invasion of lymphatic vessels by cancer cells, resulting in lymphatic congestion and edema.

Incorrect Options::

Option B - Nipple retraction: Nipple retraction or inversion can be a sign of breast cancer, but it is not the most conspicuous sign.

Option C - Puckering: Puckering or dimpling of the breast skin can be a sign of breast cancer, but it is not the most conspicuous sign..

Option D - Both nipple retraction and puckering: Nipple retraction and puckering can signal breast cancer, but the most noticeable sign is often peau d'orange.

questions.text: Which artery does not provide blood supply to the corresponding area of the dura mater among the following options?

choices.text: Middle meningeal artery – anterior cranial fossa
Accessory meningeal branch of maxillary artery – middle cranial fossa
Meningeal branch of internal carotid artery – posterior cranial fossa
Meningeal branch of anterior and posterior ethmoid artery – anterior cranial fossa

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Meningeal branch of internal carotid artery – posterior cranial fossa:

  • Meningeal branch of the internal carotid artery – posterior cranial fossa: The internal carotid artery primarily supplies the brain with blood, but it does not directly supply the dura mater in the posterior cranial fossa. Instead, the posterior cranial fossa's dura mater is mainly supplied by branches of the vertebral arteries, including the posterior meningeal arteries.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Middle meningeal artery – anterior cranial fossa: The middle meningeal artery is a branch of the maxillary artery and supplies the dura mater in the anterior cranial fossa, including the frontal and parietal regions.

Option B - Accessory meningeal branch of the maxillary artery – middle cranial fossa: The accessory meningeal branch of the maxillary artery supplies the dura mater in the middle cranial fossa, which includes the temporal and sphenoid regions.

Option D - Meningeal branch of anterior and posterior ethmoid artery – anterior cranial fossa: The meningeal branches of the anterior and posterior ethmoid arteries supply the dura mater in the anterior cranial fossa, specifically the ethmoid and frontal regions.

questions.text: Which of the following does not supply the marked structure?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Diagonal artery:

The diagonal artery does not supply the marked structure (right ventricle). The diagonal artery is a branch of the left anterior descending artery and primarily supplies the left ventricle and the anterior walls of the heart.

Incorrect Option:

Option A - The right coronary artery supplies blood to the right ventricle, which is the marked structure. It's one of the main arteries responsible for nourishing the right side of the heart..

Option B - The anterior interventricular artery, a branch of the left coronary artery, supplies blood to the interventricular septum and front walls of both ventricles, including the right ventricle.

Option C - The marginal artery, a branch of the right coronary artery, supplies blood to the right ventricle. It runs along the heart's right border, providing blood to the right ventricle's lateral wall.

questions.text: Marked structure is derived from the ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Endocardial cushions:

The endocardial cushions play a crucial role in the development of the heart's septa and valves. They contribute to the formation of various structures, including the atrial septum, ventricular septum, and the atrioventricular (AV) valves. Therefore, it is correct to say that the marked structure is derived from the endocardial cushions.

Incorrect Option:

Option B - Septum primum: During embryonic development, the septum primum grows downward from the roof of the primitive atrium but doesn't directly form the marked structure.

Option C - Left venous valve: The left venous valve regulates blood flow from the coronary sinus in the right atrium but doesn't contribute to the marked structure's formation.

Option D - Bulbous venosus: The bulbous venosus, part of the embryonic heart tube, helps form the right ventricle but doesn't directly create the marked structure.

questions.text: The region marked corresponds to the surface marking for which of the following structures:-
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Right atrium: The marked region corresponds to the surface marking for the right atrium, which aligns with the right sternal border. 

Incorrect Option:

Option A - The thoracic duct in the posterior mediastinum drains lymph from the lower and left upper body into the venous system but isn't represented by the marked region on the image.

Option C - Inferomedial bronchopulmonary segments are specific regions within the lungs. They are not related to the region marked on the image, which is external to the lungs.

Option D - The hilum is where blood vessels, nerves, and bronchi enter or exit an organ, like the hila of the lungs. However, the marked region on the image isn't the hilum.

questions.text: Sternum is attached to scapula via?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Clavicle

  • Clavicle: The clavicle is a bone that connects the sternum (specifically the manubrium) to the scapula. It forms the acromioclavicular joint with the scapula, providing a direct attachment between the sternum and the scapula. This makes option B correct.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Manubrium: The manubrium is the top portion of the sternum and forms the sternoclavicular joint with the clavicle. However, it doesn't directly connect to the scapula.

Option C - First rib: The first rib, attaching to the sternum at the sternocostal joint, isn't directly involved in connecting the sternum to the scapula.

Option D - Second rib: The second rib, like the first rib, attaches to the sternum at the sternocostal joint, but it isn't directly linked to the scapula.

questions.text:
Mediastinal surface of the right lung is related to? 

A. The Azygos vein

B. The Right Lymphatic Duct

C. The Aorta

D. The Trachea
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - A only:

  • The Azygos vein: The azygos vein is a major vein that drains blood from the posterior part of the thoracic wall into the superior vena cava. It does run along the mediastinal surface of the right lung, making option A correct.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Lymphatic vessel that drains lymph from the upper right quadrant of the body.

Option C - While the aortais located in the mediastinum, it is positioned more towards the left side rather than the mediastinal surface of the right lung.

Option D - The trachea travels down the center of the thoracic cavity, behind the mediastinal surface of both lungs. Although it's close to the mediastinal surface of the right lung, it's not directly connected to it.

questions.text: The structure not passing through the aortic opening of the diaphragm is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Vagal trunk

  • The aortic opening of the diaphragm, also known as the aortic hiatus, is an opening in the diaphragm through which structures pass between the thoracic and abdominal cavities.
  • It is located at the level of the 12th thoracic vertebra.
  • The vagal trunk comes through an esophageal opening at 10th thoracic vertebra.

Incorrect Options

Option A - Aorta: The aorta, the largest artery in the body, passes through the aortic opening of the diaphragm..

Option B - Azygous vein: The azygous vein, an important venous channel in the thorax, ascends on the right side of the vertebral column and passes through the aortic opening of the diaphragm.

Option C - Thoracic duct: The thoracic duct, the main lymphatic vessel in the body, also passes through the aortic opening of the diaphragm.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Sibson's fascia is not correct?

choices.text: Attached to the inner border of 2nd rib
Not a part of scalenus minimus muscle

questions.solution:
Correct Option A: Attached to the inner border of 2nd rib

  • Sibson's fascia attaches to the inner border of the 1st rib and covers the apical part of the lung.
  • Sibson's fascia, also known as the suprapleural membrane, is a thin layer of connective tissue located at the apex of the lung.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Covers apical part of the lung: This statement is correct. Sibson's fascia covers the apical part of the lung and forms a protective layer over the lung apex.

Option C - Not a part of scalenus minimus muscle: This statement is correct. The scalenus minimus muscle is a small muscle found in some individuals near the apex of the lung, but it is not directly associated with Sibson's fascia.

Option D - Vessels pass above the fascia: This statement is correct. Sibson's fascia shields the lung apex from blood vessels like the subclavian vessels and brachiocephalic veins.

questions.text: The joint between the attachment of the 8th and 9th rib to the 7th rib is a:
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Synovial joint

  • The joint between the attachment of the 8th and 9th rib to the 7th rib is classified as a synovial joint.
  • Synovial joints are characterized by the presence of a joint cavity filled with synovial fluid, which allows for smooth movement between the articulating surfaces.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Fibrocartilaginous joint: Fibrocartilaginous joints, like intervertebral discs and the pubic symphysis, provide stability with limited movement due to fibrocartilage between bones..

Option B - Symphyseal joint: Symphyseal joints, featuring hyaline and fibrocartilage, allow limited movement and are seen in the pubic symphysis and intervertebral discs.

Option D - Fibrous joint: Fibrous joints, like skull sutures, typically allow minimal movement due to fibrous connective tissue. However, the joint between the 8th and 9th rib attachment to the 7th rib permits movement and isn't solely fibrous.

questions.text: After a fall from a height with his hand outstretched, a man is brought to the emergency department. An X-ray reveals a fracture in the clavicle. Which specific region of the clavicle is the most likely to be fractured?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Junction of medial 2/3rd and lateral 1/3rd

  • The junction of medial 2/3rd and lateral 1/3rd of the clavicle. This is the most common site of clavicular fracture, accounting for approximately 80% of all clavicular fractures. This area is also known as the "junction" or "transition zone" because it is where the clavicle changes from a thicker, more rounded bone to a thinner, flatter bone.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Junction of medial 1/3rd and lateral 2/3rd: Clavicular fractures at this junction are rare due to its thickness and strength, needing considerable force to cause a fracture 

Option C - Junction of middle 1/3rd and medial 1/3rd: Fractures at the middle 1/3rd and medial 1/3rd junction of the clavicle are uncommon due to its thinner and more flexible nature.

Option D - Middle of the clavicle: Mid-clavicular fractures are uncommon and typically result from direct trauma or a fall onto the shoulder, rather than a fall onto an outstretched hand.

questions.text: The inferior scapular angle is at which vertebrae level?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - T7:

  • The superior scapular angle is located at T2, while the inferior scapular angle is situated at T7.

Incorrect Options:  A, C, and D are incorrect.

questions.text:
In the given section of the heart, match the marked (A,B,C&D) structures.




	Musculi pectinate 
	Anterior papillary muscle of left ventricle 
	Anterior papillary muscle of right ventricle 
	Anterior leaflet of mitral valve 
	membranous part of ventricular septum
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - A-5, B-3, C-2, D-1:

A - Membranous part of ventricular septum

B - Anterior papillary muscle of right ventricle

C - Anterior papillary muscle of left ventricle

D - Musculi pectinate


Incorrect Options - A, B & D are incorrect answer

questions.text: The image shows the cross-section of the abdominal cavity. Identify the structure marked ‘A.’
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Descending aorta:

  • The diagram focuses on the posterior mediastinum, and the marked structure is descending aorta. The round structure just in front of the vertebral column is descending aorta, slightly towards the left. The descending aorta is located posterior to the diaphragm, in the midline of the body. It is a continuation of the thoracic aorta and descends along the vertebral column in the posterior mediastinum before entering the abdominal cavity. In the abdominal cavity, it descends along the posterior wall, slightly to the left of the midline, and gives off branches to the abdominal organs.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Superior vena cava: The superior vena cava, found in the superior mediastinum, enters the right atrium of the heart. It is not visible in abdominal cavity cross-sections.

Option C - Inferior vena cava: The inferior vena cava enters the right atrium from the posterior mediastinum, traveling along the back of the abdominal wall to the right of the midline, collecting blood from the lower body and abdominal organs.

Option D - Ascending aorta: The ascending aorta begins at the left ventricle, ascends to the superior mediastinum, and branches into the brachiocephalic trunk, left common carotid artery, and left subclavian artery.
